items.title: Leveraging tax credits and incentives for sustainability projects

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Randa Barsoum, Tax Partner at PwC US, explains that while energy tax credits are the most obvious, a wider set of tax credits and incentives can support sustainability efforts. She highlights state and local abatements, location-based incentives, and R&D tax credits tied to innovation in areas like packaging or processes, and urges leaders to view sustainability investments through a broader tax lens.
bullets: Energy incentives are common but not the only tax levers for sustainability.
State and local abatements can provide meaningful tax relief for projects.
Location-based incentives may influence site and investment decisions.
R&D tax credits can apply to innovation tied to sustainability (e.g., reimagined packaging or processes).
Framing sustainability investments broadly can unlock additional tax value.
takeaways: Donâ€™t limit project tax planning to energy creditsâ€”assess state/local abatements and location-based incentives for new builds or upgrades.
Include R&D credit screening for sustainability-driven innovation in processes or materials to capture additional tax benefits.
Treat sustainability investments as potential tax-advantaged opportunities by broadening the incentive review early in project planning.

items.title: Why data is critical to sustainable supply chains

ai.summary: Based on the available description, David Linich of PwC US argues that reliable, high-quality data is essential for organizations to scenario plan, protect margins, and deliver sustainable, high-quality products at the right place and time. He emphasizes that with conditions changing week by week, data-driven decision-making is critical to building resilient, modern supply chains.
bullets: Reliable, high-quality data enables effective scenario planning.
Data helps protect margins amid shifting tariffs and margin pressure.
Data supports delivering sustainable, high-quality products on time.
Rapidly changing conditions make frequent, data-driven decisions necessary.
Focus on data underpins resilient, modern supply chain operations.
takeaways: Prioritize collecting and validating supply-chain data to support scenario planning and continuity for grid and data center projects.
Use high-quality data to anticipate cost pressures and protect margins in procurement and operations.
Leverage data to ensure sustainable sourcing and on-time delivery of critical components for infrastructure builds.
Implement processes for frequent data refreshes so decisions reflect week-to-week changes in supply conditions.

items.title: Bringing In $251K A Year With 3 Jobs In The Bay Area

ai.summary: Based on the available descriptionâ€¦Naseema McElroy, 44, is a labor and delivery nurse in Brentwood, California who started the personal finance brand Financially Intentional to document her money journey. She carried nearly $1 million in debt in 2015, became debt-free by 2017, and the video title reports she now brings in $251K a year across three jobs in the Bay Area.
bullets: Naseema McElroy, 44, is a labor and delivery nurse and founder of Financially Intentional in Brentwood, CA.
She accumulated nearly $1 million in debt in 2015 and learned to manage her money.
McElroy documented her debt-payoff journey through her business and was debt-free by 2017.
Video title states she earns $251K per year through three jobs in the Bay Area.
This profile is part of CNBC Make It's Millennial Money series; produced by Valentina Duarte and team.
takeaways: Employees may pursue multiple income streams (three jobs) â€” workforce planning should consider nontraditional work arrangements.
High personal debt levels can exist even among skilled professionals â€” financial-wellness support may improve employee stability.
Documenting personal finance journeys can build a brand and alternative revenue â€” staff side projects can create retention or PR opportunities.
Profiles like this highlight practical debt-recovery timelines (2015 debt to 2017 debt-free) that can inform realistic employee financial-education programs.

items.title: GeForce Garage - Summer of RTX Community Build

The description lists full parts (PCPartPicker link), the host (Dwight), and social links for GeForce.
bullets: Winner: u/JeffersonPutnam from the Summer of RTX community build contest.
Chassis: Fractal Design Era 2 small-form-factor; GPU: GeForce RTX 5090 Founders Edition.
CPU/RAM: Ryzen 7 9800X3D with 32GB Teamgroup T-Create Expert DDR5-6000.
Power and cooling: Corsair SF1000 SFX PSU and Corsair Nautilus 240 RS AIO.
PCPartPicker list and GeForce host (Dwight) linked in the description.
takeaways: Compact SFF chassis housing an RTX 5090 shows high-end GPUs can be integrated into small enclosuresâ€”plan for thermal and spatial constraints when density matters.
Use of a 1000W SFX PSU indicates significant power provisioning is required even in compact buildsâ€”account for power delivery and connector compatibility.
A 240mm AIO cooler in an SFF build highlights the need for robust cooling solutions for high-performance components in tight enclosures.
Pairing a high-end consumer GPU with a high-performance CPU and DDR5-6000 RAM suggests balanced system design is important when specifying nodes for GPU-accelerated workloads.
Published parts list (PCPartPicker) and community build visibility support reproducibility and transparent procurement for similar configurations.
